result.query:
Please find the name of the catalyst and co-catalyst name from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
Please only generate the name of the catalyst and nothing else. Such as TiO2. ZrO2 or Ag, etc.
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
If there are multiple results, please indicate them as XXX-XXX.
catalyst: XXX
co_catalyst: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: catalyst powder (0.1 g) was dispersed on the stainless omentum which was fixed in the center of reactor.Prior to illumination, the reactor was vacuumed and purged with the CO 2 H 2 O mixture at about 20 mLmin for 2 h to establish an adsorption-desorption balance.After that, the reactor was tightly closed and the Hg lamp was then switched on to start the experiment.The distance between the substrate and Hg lamp was 15 cm, the reaction temperature and pressure were maintained at 30 1C and 110 kPa,

3 shows the evolution of CO as a function of irradiation time over two catalysts.From the curves, it is found that the yield of CO is increased with the irradiation time for both catalysts, and the Meso-g-C 3 N 4 exhibits much higher activity than flake-like g-C 3 N 4 .After 7 h of irradiation, the yield of CO on the Meso-g-C 3 N 4 is up to 3.48 mmol g A 1 cat.The excellent photocatalytic activity of the Meso-g-C 3 N 4 sample can be attributed to its unique 3D open-pore system which facilitates the

system which facilitates the reactant diffusion into the bulk of catalyst and hence provide fast intraparticle molecular transfer.Meanwhile, the high surface area can enhance the light harvesting as well as the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules.

order and textural properties of the obtained meso-g-C 3 N 4 were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (Bruker D8 Advance), nitrogen physical sorption (Beishide 3H-2000PS4) and transmission electron microscopy (JEOL JEM-2010).UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of the samples were recorded on a Shimadezu UV-2401 spectrophotometer. The photocatalytic activity of the Meso-g-C 3 N 4 was evaluated by photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O under UV light.Typically, catalyst powder (0.1 g) was

the DRS result.The improved characteristics for the Meso-g-C 3 N 4 may be ascribed to its ordered mesoporous structure, enlarged surface area and multiple scatting enable it to harvest light more efficiently 18,19.One of the promising applications of graphitic carbon nitrides is that they can function as photocatalysts for environmental and energy applications.Herein, Meso-g-C 3 N 4 and flake-like g-C 3 N 4 were tested for the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O.
